overview_of_class: In dystopian stories the ills of society run riot. As a film genre, dystopian owes much to satire, science fiction, and fantasy and yet is distinct from them. Examples include: The Hunger Games, Children of Men, and The Handmaid's Tale. In this class, we will view and discuss examples of dystopian films in order to understand the conventions of the genre, the anxieties it explores, and why these stories captivate today's audiences. By the end of the quarter, students will complete an original screenplay for a short film (20 to 30 minutes) or a treatment for a feature film, detailing a three-act story, and a completed first act.

overview_of_class: Students will learn how to create a feature-length screenplay for a limited budget. By creating and workshopping a completed first or second draft of a script, students will learn about story structure, autobiography, self-production, creative casting and other do-it-yourself aspects of starting and finishing a microbudget movie.

overview_of_class: The author of The Walking Dead novels leads this workshop-oriented class on the latest state of the art in screenwriting for this ancient genre, which keeps getting reinvented over and over again - from GET OUT to THE CONJURING. The goal of the course is to create a fully developed first act and outline for a feature length horror screenplay that stands beside the best of this new generation of scares.

overview_of_class: From the lovers' furniture-throwing spat, to the courtroom battle, to rage-fueled, drunken debates over right and wrong, to verbal duels of all types, the crafting of a compelling argument for the stage or screen is a necessary skill for all writers of dramatic narrative. This course will have students take a close look at some of the greatest Word Wars of theater and film, with an eye to seeing how they work, and the goal of writing some fresh fights for this age.
